conclusion: Identify the given information for states A, B, and C.
State A: Volume \( V_A = 6 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{m}^3 \), Pressure \( P_A = 1 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \), Temperature \( T_A = 27^\circ \text{C} = 300 \, \text{K} \).
State B: Volume \( V_B = 6 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{m}^3 \), Pressure \( P_B = 2 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \).
State C: Volume \( V_C = 3 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{m}^3 \), Pressure \( P_C = 3 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \).
Use the ideal gas law: \( PV = nRT \).
For states A and B, use the relation \( \frac{P_A}{T_A} = \frac{P_B}{T_B} \) since the volume remains constant.
Rearrange the equation to solve for \( T_B \): \( T_B = T_A \times \frac{P_B}{P_A} \).
The temperature of the gas in state B is \( 600 \, \text{K} \).
